comment_text.mn99:2.1: The same Subha later met the Buddha in MN 135, where he asked about kamma, and, following the Buddha’s passing, met with Ānanda in DN 10. | Subha’s father Todeyya was a prominent brahmin, often mentioned alongside Pokkharasāti. The two apparently lived not far from each other, as, according to the commentary, Todeyya was named for his village of Tudi outside of Sāvatthī (see Pāṇini’s Aṣṭādhyāyī 4.3.94).
comment_text.mn99:2.3: This passage suggests this was Subha’s first meeting with the Buddha.
comment_text.mn99:4.2: The “the system of the skillful teaching” (or perhaps “principle”, ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ), though attributed to the brahmins, is a very Buddhist-sounding phrase; I have not been able to identify anything similar in Brahmanical texts. The sentiment, however, is Brahmanical, since Vedism was for a long time practiced by householders, and the renunciate path advocated by Yājñavalkya was still controversial (see eg. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.22).
comment_text.mn99:4.4: “One who speaks after analyzing the question” is vibhajjavāda, a term that in later years characterized the Buddha’s teachings as a whole, or else a school or group of schools of whom the Sri Lankan Theravāda was one. The term is also used in Jainism (Sūyagaḍa 14.22).
comment_text.mn99:9.2: Given that this is said to be a practice for householders, it would seem that tapas here means “fervor” rather than “mortification”. | A somewhat similar list of four things is found at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.22: a brahmin realizes the Self by means of study of Vedas, sacrifice, generosity, and the fervor of fasting (vedānuvacanena … yajñena dānena tapasānāśakena). Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.5.3 further identifies fasting with brahmacariya and living in the forest.
comment_text.mn99:10.3: The Subhaga Forest outside Ukkaṭṭha was the scene of cosmic drama demonstrating the superiority of the Buddha over the brahmins, likely chosen because it was Pokkharasāti’s home (MN 1:1.2, MN 49:2.1; see also DN 14:3.29). | The Upamañña clan (gotra) traces to Upamanyu Vāsiṣṭha, the author of three verses in homage of Indra and Soma (Rig Veda 9.97.13–15). The association with Soma worship continued with Prācīnaśāla son of Upamanyu, who worshiped the Self in the sky only, which, though limited, brings an abundance of Soma libations and food in the family (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 5.12; cf. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1.3). An Upamanyu descendant hailed from Kamboja (Persia); his teacher Madragāra Śauṅgāyani was from the neighboring Madra (Vaṁśa-Brāhmaṇa 1.17). It is perhaps this Upamanyu who is cited for his linguistic expertise in Yāska’s Nirukta (1.1, etc.). Insofar as any conclusions can be drawn from all this, it agrees with the sutta depiction of Pokkharasāti as a family man, devoted to Brahmanical traditions, and learned in the Vedas. Later, the Purāṇas would depict an Upamanyu as a devotee of Śiva.
comment_text.mn99:10.7: This attitude sharply contrasts with DN 3:1.2.6, where he is inspired to hear of the Buddha’s reputation for meditative insight. Presumably this was earlier. He may have grown more interested in the Buddha over time, as his reputation spread.
comment_text.mn99:12.12: A logic still all too familiar today.
comment_text.mn99:15.5: For ophuṭo compare sabbavāriphuṭo at MN 56:12.2. In both cases phuṭ appears in a string of terms from the root var, and is possibly a corrupted form, or at least has the same meaning.
comment_text.mn99:19.6: The same thought can occur to mendicants too (MN 5:15.2).
comment_text.mn99:19.16: Accepting his initial idea of generosity in deed, the Buddha leads Subha to agree on the importance of inner motivation as well.
comment_text.mn99:23.3: As at DN 13:39.2. Sāriputta teaches a similar path at MN 97:31.3, but without being asked.
comment_text.mn99:28.4: He is said to have gone for refuge again in MN 135:21.4 and DN 10:2.37.9.
comment_text.mn99:28.7: Echoing his earlier acknowledgment of the many duties of lay folk at MN 99:5.2.

root_text.mn99:17.2: yaṁ vā tiṇakaṭṭhupādānaṁ paṭicca aggiṁ jāleyya yaṁ vā nissaṭṭhatiṇakaṭṭhupādānaṁ aggiṁ jāleyya, katamo nu khvāssa aggi accimā ceva vaṇṇavā ca pabhassaro cā”ti?
root_text.mn99:17.3: “Sace taṁ, bho gotama, ṭhānaṁ nissaṭṭhatiṇakaṭṭhupādānaṁ aggiṁ jāletuṁ, svāssa aggi accimā ceva vaṇṇavā ca pabhassaro cā”ti.
root_text.mn99:17.4: “Aṭṭhānaṁ kho etaṁ, māṇava, anavakāso yaṁ nissaṭṭhatiṇakaṭṭhupādānaṁ aggiṁ jāleyya aññatra iddhimatā.
root_text.mn99:17.5: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, tiṇakaṭṭhupādānaṁ paṭicca aggi jalati tathūpamāhaṁ, māṇava, imaṁ pītiṁ vadāmi yāyaṁ pīti pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca.
root_text.mn99:17.6: Seyyathāpi, māṇava, nissaṭṭhatiṇakaṭṭhupādāno aggi jalati tathūpamāhaṁ, māṇava, imaṁ pītiṁ vadāmi yāyaṁ pīti aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi.
root_text.mn99:17.7: Katamā ca, māṇava, pīti aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi?
root_text.mn99:17.8: Idha, māṇava, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn99:17.9: Ayampi kho, māṇava, pīti aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi.

root_text.mn99:17.11: Ayampi kho, māṇava, pīti aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehi.
root_text.mn99:18.1: Ye te, māṇava, brāhmaṇā pañca dhamme paññapenti puññassa kiriyāya kusalassa ārādhanāya, katamettha brāhmaṇā dhammaṁ mahapphalataraṁ paññapenti puññassa kiriyāya kusalassa ārādhanāyā”ti?

root_text.mn99:20.1: “Ye te, māṇava, brāhmaṇā pañca dhamme paññapenti puññassa kiriyāya kusalassa ārādhanāya, ime tvaṁ pañca dhamme kattha bahulaṁ samanupassasi—

root_text.mn99:22.13: “Siyā nu kho, māṇava, tassa purisassa naḷakāragāme jātavaddhassa naḷakāragāmassa maggaṁ puṭṭhassa dandhāyitattaṁ vā vitthāyitattaṁ vāti, na tveva tathāgatassa brahmalokaṁ vā brahmalokagāminiṁ vā paṭipadaṁ puṭṭhassa dandhāyitattaṁ vā vitthāyitattaṁ vā.

root_text.mn99:28.3: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.

root_text.mn99:30.1: Tena kho pana samayena jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo sabbasetena vaḷavābhirathena sāvatthiyā niyyāti divā divassa.
root_text.mn99:30.2: Addasā kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo subhaṁ māṇavaṁ todeyyaputtaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.

root_text.mn99:30.8: Sopi nūnassa tādisova yo samaṇassa gotamassa paññāveyyattiyaṁ jāneyyā”ti.

translation_text.mn99:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn99:2.1: Now at that time the student Subha, Todeyya’s son, was residing in Sāvatthī at a certain householder’s home on some business.
translation_text.mn99:2.2: Then Subha said to that householder,
translation_text.mn99:2.4: Sāvatthī does not lack for perfected ones.
translation_text.mn99:2.5: What ascetic or brahmin might we pay homage to today?”
translation_text.mn99:2.6: “Sir, the Buddha is staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn99:2.7: You can pay homage to him.”
translation_text.mn99:3.1: Acknowledging that householder, Subha went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn99:3.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn99:4.2: ‘Laypeople succeed in the system of the skillful teaching, not renunciates.’
translation_text.mn99:4.3: What do you say about this?”
translation_text.mn99:4.4: “On this point, student, I speak after analyzing the question,
translation_text.mn99:4.6: I don’t praise wrong practice for either laypeople or renunciates.
translation_text.mn99:4.7: Because of wrong practice, neither laypeople nor renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.
translation_text.mn99:4.8: I praise right practice for both laypeople and renunciates.
translation_text.mn99:4.9: Because of right practice, both laypeople and renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.”

translation_text.mn99:5.4: What do you say about this?”

translation_text.mn99:5.8: Some work has many obligations, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful.

translation_text.mn99:9.8: “Well, student, is there even a single one of the brahmins who says this:
translation_text.mn99:9.9: ‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight’?”
translation_text.mn99:9.11: “Well, is there even a single tutor of the brahmins, or a tutor’s tutor, or anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors, who says this:
translation_text.mn99:9.12: ‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight’?”
translation_text.mn99:9.14: “Well, what of the ancient seers of the brahmins, namely Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu? Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught.
translation_text.mn99:9.16: ‘We declare the result of these five things after realizing it with our own insight’?”
translation_text.mn99:9.18: “So, student, it seems that there is not a single one of the brahmins,
translation_text.mn99:9.20: not even anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors,
translation_text.mn99:9.22: nor even the ancient seers of the brahmins
translation_text.mn99:9.24: ‘We declare the result of these five things after realizing it with our own insight.’
translation_text.mn99:9.25: Suppose there was a queue of blind men, each holding the one in front: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
translation_text.mn99:9.26: In the same way, it seems to me that the brahmins’ statement turns out to be comparable to a queue of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.”
translation_text.mn99:10.1: When he said this, Subha became angry and upset with the Buddha because of the simile of the queue of blind men. He even attacked and badmouthed the Buddha himself, saying,
translation_text.mn99:10.2: “The ascetic Gotama will be worsted!” He said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn99:10.3: “Worthy Gotama, the brahmin Pokkharasāti Upamañña of the Subhaga Forest says:
translation_text.mn99:10.4: ‘This is exactly what happens with some ascetics and brahmins. They claim to have a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
translation_text.mn99:10.5: But their statement turns out to be a joke—mere words, vacuous and hollow.
translation_text.mn99:10.6: For how on earth can a human being know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones?
translation_text.mn99:11.1: “But student, does Pokkharasāti understand the minds of all these ascetics and brahmins, having encompassed them with his mind?”
translation_text.mn99:11.2: “Worthy Gotama, Pokkharasāti doesn’t even know the mind of his own bonded maid Puṇṇikā, so how could he know all those ascetics and brahmins?”

translation_text.mn99:13.1: “In the same way, Pokkharasāti is blind and sightless.
translation_text.mn99:13.2: It is quite impossible for him to know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
translation_text.mn99:13.4: There are well-to-do brahmins of Kosala such as

translation_text.mn99:13.9: “What’s better for them: that their speech follows reflection or is unreflective?”
translation_text.mn99:13.11: “What’s better for them: that their speech is beneficial or worthless?”

translation_text.mn99:17.2: Which would have better flames, color, and radiance: a fire that depends on grass and logs as fuel, or one that does not?”
translation_text.mn99:17.3: “If it were possible for a fire to burn without depending on grass and logs as fuel, that would have better flames, color, and radiance.”
translation_text.mn99:17.4: “But it isn’t possible, except by psychic power.
translation_text.mn99:17.5: Rapture that depends on the five kinds of sensual stimulation is like a fire that depends on grass and logs as fuel.
translation_text.mn99:17.6: Rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities is like a fire that doesn’t depend on grass and logs as fuel.
translation_text.mn99:17.7: And what is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities?
translation_text.mn99:17.8: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn99:17.9: This is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.
translation_text.mn99:17.10: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn99:17.11: This too is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.

translation_text.mn99:19.5: Then one of those brahmins thought:

translation_text.mn99:19.7: But it’s possible that some other brahmin gets the best seat, the best drink, and the best almsfood in the refectory.
translation_text.mn99:19.8: Thinking, ‘Some other brahmin has got the best seat, the best drink, the best almsfood,’
translation_text.mn99:19.10: What do the brahmins say is the result of this?”
translation_text.mn99:19.11: “Worthy Gotama, brahmins don’t give gifts so that

translation_text.mn99:19.13: Rather, they give only out of sympathy.”
translation_text.mn99:19.14: “In that case, isn’t compassion a sixth ground for making merit?”
translation_text.mn99:19.16: “In that case, compassion is a sixth ground for making merit.”

translation_text.mn99:20.14: Of the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful, I usually find them among renunciates, and less so among laypeople.”

translation_text.mn99:21.3: Take a mendicant who speaks the truth.

translation_text.mn99:21.12: And I say that joy connected with the skillful is a prerequisite of the mind for

translation_text.mn99:22.1: When he had spoken, Subha said to him,
translation_text.mn99:22.3: the ascetic Gotama knows a path to company with divinity.”
translation_text.mn99:22.5: Is the village of Naḷakāra nearby?”
translation_text.mn99:22.7: “What do you think, student? Suppose a person was born and raised in Naḷakāra.
translation_text.mn99:22.8: And as soon as they left the town some people asked them for the road to Naḷakāra.
translation_text.mn99:22.9: Would they be slow or hesitant to answer?”
translation_text.mn99:22.12: Because they were born and raised in Naḷakāra. They’re well acquainted with all the roads to the village.”
translation_text.mn99:22.13: “Still, it’s possible they might be slow or hesitant to answer. But the Realized One is never slow or hesitant when questioned about the realm of divinity or the practice that leads to the realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn99:22.14: I understand divinity, the realm of divinity, and the practice that leads to the realm of divinity, practicing in accordance with which one is reborn in the realm of divinity.”
translation_text.mn99:23.2: the ascetic Gotama teaches a path to company with divinity.
translation_text.mn99:23.4: “Well then, student, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn99:24.1: “And what is a path to company with divinity?
translation_text.mn99:24.2: Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn99:24.3: When the heart’s release by love has been developed like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
translation_text.mn99:24.4: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four quarters.
translation_text.mn99:24.5: In the same way, when the heart’s release by love has been developed like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
translation_text.mn99:24.6: This is a path to company with divinity.
translation_text.mn99:25-27.1: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …
translation_text.mn99:25-27.2: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
translation_text.mn99:25-27.3: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn99:25-27.4: When the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
translation_text.mn99:25-27.5: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four quarters.
translation_text.mn99:25-27.6: In the same way, when the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
translation_text.mn99:25-27.7: This too is a path to company with divinity.”
translation_text.mn99:28.1: When he had spoken, Subha said to him,
translation_text.mn99:28.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn99:28.4: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn99:28.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
translation_text.mn99:28.6: Well, now, worthy Gotama, I must go.
translation_text.mn99:28.7: I have many duties, and much to do.”
translation_text.mn99:29.2: And then Subha approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.mn99:30.1: Now at that time the brahmin Jānussoṇi drove out from Sāvatthī in the middle of the day in an all-white chariot drawn by mares.
translation_text.mn99:30.2: He saw the student Subha coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn99:30.4: “So, worthy Bhāradvāja, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”
translation_text.mn99:30.5: “Just now, good fellow, I’ve come from the presence of the ascetic Gotama.”
translation_text.mn99:30.6: “What do you think of the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom? Do you think he’s astute?”
translation_text.mn99:30.7: “My good man, who am I to judge the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom?
translation_text.mn99:30.8: You’d really have to be on the same level to judge his lucidity of wisdom.”
translation_text.mn99:30.9: “Mister Bhāradvāja praises the ascetic Gotama with high praise indeed.”
translation_text.mn99:30.10: “Who am I to praise the ascetic Gotama?
translation_text.mn99:30.11: He is praised by the praised as the best among gods and humans.
translation_text.mn99:30.12: The five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful
translation_text.mn99:30.13: he says are prerequisites of the mind for
translation_text.mn99:30.14: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.”
translation_text.mn99:31.1: When he had spoken, Jānussoṇi got down from his chariot, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times,
translation_text.mn99:31.2: “King Pasenadi of Kosala is lucky, so very lucky
translation_text.mn99:31.3: that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is living in his realm!”
